message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Survey on Hypergraph Mining: Patterns, Tools, and Generators
Paper Abstract: Hypergraphs, which belong to the family of higher-order networks, are a natural and powerful choice for modeling group interactions in the real world. For example, when modeling collaboration networks, which may involve not just two but three or more people, the use of hypergraphs allows us to explore beyond pairwise (dyadic) patterns and capture groupwise (polyadic) patterns. The mathematical complexity of hypergraphs offers both opportunities and challenges for hypergraph mining. The goal of hypergraph mining is to find structural properties recurring in real-world hypergraphs across different domains, which we call patterns. To find patterns, we need tools. We divide hypergraph mining tools into three categories: (1) null models (which help test the significance of observed patterns), (2) structural elements (i.e., substructures in a hypergraph such as open and closed triangles), and (3) structural quantities (i.e., numerical tools for computing hypergraph patterns such as transitivity). There are also hypergraph generators, whose objective is to produce synthetic hypergraphs that are a faithful representation of real-world hypergraphs. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive overview of the current landscape of hypergraph mining, covering patterns, tools, and generators. We provide comprehensive taxonomies for each and offer in-depth discussions for future research on hypergraph mining.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph"},{"title":"Line graph of a hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_graph_of_a_hypergraph"},{"title":"Balanced hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balanced_hypergraph"},{"title":"Bipartite hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartite_hypergraph"},{"title":"Packing in a hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packing_in_a_hypergraph"},{"title":"Hypergraph removal lemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph_removal_lemma"},{"title":"Discrepancy of hypergraphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrepancy_of_hypergraphs"},{"title":"Matching in hypergraphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matching_in_hypergraphs"},{"title":"Hypergraph regularity method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph_regularity_method"},{"title":"D-interval hypergraph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D-interval_hypergraph"}]

## Hypergraph

A hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices.(no content)In contrast, in an ordinary graph, an edge connects exactly two vertices.

### Key Characteristics

A hypergraph is a pair (V, E), where V is a set of vertices and E is a set of subsets of V called hyperedges, where each hyperedge may contain one or more vertices.

### Variations

Hypergraphs can take different forms:

- An undirected hypergraph is also called a set system or a family of sets drawn from the set of elements.
- A hypergraph whose edges all have size k is called k-uniform (a 2-uniform hypergraph is a graph).

### Applications

Undirected hypergraphs are useful in modelling such things as satisfiability problems, databases, machine learning, and Steiner tree problems, and have been extensively used in machine learning tasks with applications including recommender systems, image retrieval, and bioinformatics.

### Mathematical Methods

The hypergraph regularity method is a powerful tool in extremal graph theory that refers to the combined application of the hypergraph regularity lemma and the associated counting lemma, and is a generalization of the graph regularity method.

Web search results for query: "Triangle closed graph"

Links: [{"title":"Triadic closure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triadic_closure"},{"title":"Triangle graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangle_graph"},{"title":"Triangle-free graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangle-free_graph"},{"title":"Clustering coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clustering_coefficient"},{"title":"Ternary plot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ternary_plot"},{"title":"Closed graph theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_graph_theorem"},{"title":"Grötzsch graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gr%C3%B6tzsch_graph"},{"title":"Closed graph theorem (functional analysis) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_graph_theorem_(functional_analysis)"},{"title":"Triangular function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangular_function"},{"title":"Graph removal lemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_removal_lemma"}]

Based on the search results, here are the main concepts related to "triangle closed graph":

## Triadic Closure

Triadic closure is the property among three nodes A, B, and C that if the connections A-B and A-C exist, there is a tendency for the new connection B-C to be formed.(no content)Triadic closure is a good model for how networks will evolve over time, and applying the triadic closure principle can predict the development of ties within a network and show the progression of connectivity.(no content)The two most common measures of triadic closure for a graph are the clustering coefficient and transitivity for that graph.

## Triangle Graph

In the mathematical field of graph theory, the triangle graph is a planar undirected graph with 3 vertices and 3 edges, in the form of a triangle.(no content)The triangle graph has chromatic number 3, chromatic index 3, radius 1, diameter 1 and girth 3, and is both a 2-vertex-connected graph and a 2-edge-connected graph.

## Related Concepts

- **Triangle-free graphs**: A triangle-free graph is an undirected graph in which no three vertices form a triangle of edges.

- **Closed triplets**: A triplet is three nodes that are connected by either two (open triplet) or three (closed triplet) undirected ties.

Here are the search results for "Graph theory":

## Overview

In mathematics and computer science, graph theory is the study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects.(no content)A graph in this context is made up of vertices (also called nodes or points) which are connected by edges (also called arcs, links or lines).

## Historical Origins

The paper written by Leonhard Euler on the Seven Bridges of Königsberg and published in 1736 is regarded as the first paper in the history of graph theory.

## Applications

Graph theory has diverse applications across many fields:

- **Chemistry & Physics**: In chemistry a graph makes a natural model for a molecule, where vertices represent atoms and edges bonds.

- **Linguistics**: Graph-theoretic methods, in various forms, have proven particularly useful in linguistics, since natural language often lends itself well to discrete structure.

- **Sociology**: Graph theory is also widely used in sociology as a way, for example, to measure actors' prestige or to explore rumor spreading, notably through the use of social network analysis software.

- **Biology**: Graph theory is useful in biology and conservation efforts where a vertex can represent regions where certain species exist (or inhabit) and the edges represent migration paths or movement between the regions.

- **Transportation & GPS**: Such weighted graphs are commonly used to program GPS's, and travel-planning search engines that compare flight times and costs.

Based on the search results, here's information about collaboration networks:

## Definition

A collaborative network consists of entities (such as organizations and people) that are largely autonomous, geographically distributed, and heterogeneous in their operating environment, culture, social capital and goals, but that collaborate to better achieve common or compatible goals, and whose interactions are supported by computer networks.

## Key Types

There are several important manifestations of collaboration networks:

- **Scientific Collaboration Networks**: A social network where nodes are scientists and links are co-authorships as the latter is one of the most well documented forms of scientific collaboration.

- **Collaborative Innovation Networks (CoINs)**: A collaborative innovation practice that uses internet platforms to promote communication and innovation within self-organizing virtual teams.

- **Social Collaboration**: While social networking is individual-centric, social collaboration is entirely group-centric, meaning working socially to achieve a common goal, for example, GitHub and Quora.

## Characteristics

The discipline of collaborative networks focuses on the structure, behavior, and evolving dynamics of networks of autonomous entities that collaborate to better achieve common or compatible goals.(no content)Key characteristics include dispersed membership with technology allowing members to be spread worldwide, and reliance on trust where cooperative behavior and mutual trust are needed to work efficiently within the network.

Links: [{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"The Science Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Science_Network"},{"title":"Linked: The New Science of Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked:_The_New_Science_of_Networks"},{"title":"Energy Sciences Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_Sciences_Network"},{"title":"Category:Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Network_science"},{"title":"Social Science Research Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Science_Research_Network"},{"title":"Fellows of the Network Science Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fellows_of_the_Network_Science_Society"},{"title":"Similarity (network science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Similarity_(network_science)"},{"title":"Efficiency (network science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Efficiency_(network_science)"},{"title":"National Science Foundation Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Science_Foundation_Network"}]

Here are the search results for "Network science":

## Overview

Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).(no content)The United States National Research Council defines network science as "the study of network representations of physical, biological, and social phenomena leading to predictive models of these phenomena."

## Interdisciplinary Foundations

The field draws on theories and methods including graph theory from mathematics, statistical mechanics from physics, data mining and information visualization from computer science, inferential modeling from statistics, and social structure from sociology.

## History and Key Developments

Interest in networks exploded around 2000, following new discoveries that offered novel mathematical framework to describe different network topologies, leading to the term 'network science'. Albert-László Barabási and Reka Albert discovered the scale-free networks nature of many real networks, from the WWW to the cell.

## Applications

Network science has numerous real-world applications. Social network analysis has been used to understand the diffusion of innovation, news and rumors.(no content)Similarly, it has been used to examine the spread of both diseases and health-related behaviors.(no content)In criminology, it is being used to identify influential actors in criminal gangs, offender movements, co-offending, predict criminal activities and make policies.

Based on the search results, here's information about graph pattern mining:

## Overview

Graph mining is a special case of structured data mining, and structured data mining is the process of finding and extracting useful information from semi-structured data sets.

## Key Concepts

**Network Motifs:** Network motifs are recurrent and statistically significant subgraphs or patterns of a larger graph. Network motifs are sub-graphs that repeat themselves in a specific network or even among various networks. A recurrent pattern is significant if the frequency of the pattern in the target graph is higher than its arithmetic mean frequency in random graphs.

**Applications:** All networks, including biological networks, social networks, technological networks (e.g., computer networks and electrical circuits) and more, can be represented as graphs.

## Related Areas

Molecule mining is the process of data mining as applied to molecules, and since molecules may be represented by molecular graphs, this is strongly related to graph mining and structured data mining.

## Computational Challenges

Although network motifs may provide a deep insight into the network's functional abilities, their detection is computationally challenging. Various algorithms have been proposed for network motif discovery and can be classified under paradigms such as exact counting methods, sampling methods, and pattern growth methods.

Graph mining is a special case of structured data mining, and structured data mining is the process of finding and extracting useful information from semi-structured data sets.

## Key Concepts

**Network Motifs:** Network motifs are recurrent and statistically significant subgraphs or patterns of a larger graph. Network motifs are sub-graphs that repeat themselves in a specific network or even among various networks. A recurrent pattern is significant if the frequency of the pattern in the target graph is higher than its arithmetic mean frequency in random graphs.

**Applications:** All networks, including biological networks, social networks, technological networks (e.g., computer networks and electrical circuits) and more, can be represented as graphs.

## Related Areas

Molecule mining is the process of data mining as applied to molecules, and since molecules may be represented by molecular graphs, this is strongly related to graph mining and structured data mining.

## Computational Challenges

Although network motifs may provide a deep insight into the network's functional abilities, their detection is computationally challenging. Various algorithms have been proposed for network motif discovery and can be classified under paradigms such as exact counting methods, sampling methods, and pattern growth methods.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about transitivity networks:

## Network Transitivity

In the context of social and network analysis, an individual's assumption of network closure (i.e. that their friends are also friends) is called transitivity. This concept is closely related to how networks develop and become interconnected.

## Measuring Transitivity

Transitivity is a measure that gives an indication of the clustering in the whole network (global), and can be applied to both undirected and directed networks. The two most common measures of triadic closure for a graph are the clustering coefficient and transitivity for that graph.

## Related Concepts

The search results also reveal several related network concepts:

- **Triadic Closure**: Triadic closure is the property among three nodes A, B, and C (representing people, for instance), that if the connections A-B and A-C exist, there is a tendency for the new connection B-C to be formed.

- **Graph Transitivity**: In graph theory, there are several types of transitive graphs, including vertex-transitive and edge-transitive graphs, which relate to the symmetry properties of graphs rather than network clustering.

- **Temporal Networks**: A component may be defined as transitively connected if transitivity holds for the subset of nodes in that component, which applies to time-varying networks.

Links: [{"title":"Null model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_model"},{"title":"Null hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_hypothesis"},{"title":"Null distribution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_distribution"},{"title":"Statistical hypothesis test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_hypothesis_testing"},{"title":"Wald test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wald_test"},{"title":"False discovery rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_discovery_rate"},{"title":"Vuong's closeness test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vuong's_closeness_test"},{"title":"Foundations of statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundations_of_statistics"},{"title":"One-way analysis of variance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_analysis_of_variance"},{"title":"Statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistics"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about null model statistics:

## Overview

A null model is a type of random object that matches one specific object in some of its features, or more generally satisfies a collection of constraints, but which is otherwise taken to be an unbiasedly random structure.(no content)The null model is used as a term of comparison, to verify whether the object in question displays some non-trivial features.

## Role in Statistical Testing

In practice, a statistic is computed based on the experimental data and the probability of obtaining a value greater than that statistic under a default or "null" model is compared to a predetermined threshold.(no content)In statistical hypothesis testing, the null distribution is the probability distribution of the test statistic when the null hypothesis is true.(no content)For example, in an F-test, the null distribution is an F-distribution.

## Applications

One important application of null models is in network analysis. The null model is the basic concept behind the definition of modularity, a function which evaluates the goodness of partitions of a graph into clusters. In particular, modularity measures the difference between the number of links from/to each pair of communities, from that expected in a graph that is completely random in all respects other than the set of degrees of each of the vertices.

T. Williams - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W._T._Williams"},{"title":"Cluster algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_algebra"}]

Here are the search results for **Clustering Coefficient**:

## Definition

In graph theory, a clustering coefficient is a measure of the degree to which nodes in a graph tend to cluster together.

## Types

Two versions of this measure exist: the global and the local. The global version was designed to give an overall indication of the clustering in the network, whereas the local gives an indication of the extent of "clustering" of a single node.

- **Local Clustering Coefficient**: The local clustering coefficient of a vertex (node) in a graph quantifies how close its neighbours are to being a clique (complete graph).

- **Global Clustering Coefficient**: The global clustering coefficient is the number of closed triplets (or 3 x triangles) over the total number of triplets (both open and closed).

## Historical Background

Duncan J. Watts and Steven Strogatz introduced the measure in 1998 to determine whether a graph is a small-world network.

## Real-World Applications

In most real-world networks, and in particular social networks, nodes tend to create tightly knit groups characterised by a relatively high density of ties; this likelihood tends to be greater than the average probability of a tie randomly established between two nodes.

## Related Concepts

A small-world network is a graph characterized by a high clustering coefficient and low distances. In an example of a social network, high clustering implies the high probability that two friends of one person are friends themselves.

Two versions of this measure exist: the global and the local. The global version was designed to give an overall indication of the clustering in the network, whereas the local gives an indication of the extent of "clustering" of a single node.

- **Local Clustering Coefficient**: The local clustering coefficient of a vertex (node) in a graph quantifies how close its neighbours are to being a clique (complete graph).

- **Global Clustering Coefficient**: The global clustering coefficient is the number of closed triplets (or 3 x triangles) over the total number of triplets (both open and closed).

## Historical Background

Duncan J. Watts and Steven Strogatz introduced the measure in 1998 to determine whether a graph is a small-world network.

## Real-World Applications

In most real-world networks, and in particular social networks, nodes tend to create tightly knit groups characterised by a relatively high density of ties; this likelihood tends to be greater than the average probability of a tie randomly established between two nodes.

## Related Concepts

A small-world network is a graph characterized by a high clustering coefficient and low distances. In an example of a social network, high clustering implies the high probability that two friends of one person are friends themselves.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as 'contribution' or 'survey'. Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=['en.wikipedia.org'] to search '[entity name]' to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence).

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=['en.wikipedia.org'] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Summary

I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "A Survey on Hypergraph Mining: Patterns, Tools, and Generators":

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: Survey (not contribution)
- **Reasoning**: The paper provides a comprehensive literature review and overview of existing hypergraph mining work, taxonomies for patterns, tools, and generators, rather than proposing new methods.

### Extracted Triples (8 total)
All triples are marked with **relation: "uses"** (as is appropriate for a survey paper that reviews existing work):

1. **Hypergraph** (concept) - The primary mathematical structure being mined
2. **Network science** (concept) - Theoretical foundation for higher-order networks
3. **Collaborative network** (concept) - Real-world application example
4. **Graph theory** (concept) - Mathematical foundation for hypergraph structures
5. **Triadic closure** (concept) - Central to understanding structural patterns
6. **Clustering coefficient** (method) - Tool for measuring hypergraph patterns
7. **Network motif** (concept) - Recurring patterns that mining seeks to discover
8. **Null model** (method) - Tool for testing pattern significance

### Validation Results
✅ **VALIDATION PASSED** - All checks successful
- Paper Type: survey
- Triples: 8
- Entity Types: 6 concepts, 2 methods
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct

The triples_output.json file has been fully populated and validated according to all requirements.
